definition: erhua variant of 大伙[da4 huo3]
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
meals (abbr. for 伙食[huo3 shi2])/variant of 夥|伙[huo3]
companion/partner/group/classifier for groups of people/to combine/together
variant of 人[ren2]/"person" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 10), occurring in 兒, 兀, 兄 etc

sentences.english: The sky rains and lightnings, they are scared and run immediately.
sentences.chinese: 天空立即落起大雨，而且行雷闪电，大伙儿立即。

sentences.english: People would have laughed at me… a cellar rat selling real estate.
sentences.chinese: 大伙儿会笑话我的，一只住地下室的耗子卖房地产。

sentences.english: I'll go and pick us some grapefruits .
After some discussion, they all trooped out of the cave and started a march on Landlord Wang's home.
sentences.chinese: 经过一番讨论后，大伙儿涌出窑洞，朝着王常盈家冲。

sentences.english: When we met in the street the houses had grown somber.
sentences.chinese: 大伙儿在街上碰头时，四周的房子都已黯淡下来。

sentences.english: The team lost and felt they had let the coach down.
sentences.chinese: 球队输了球，大伙儿觉得对不起教练。

sentences.english: Sam: Say, Adam, I'm having a barbecue at my house on December 13th.
sentences.chinese: 我说，亚当，我12月13号请大伙儿来我家烤肉。

sentences.english: This name of Brujon is one of the souvenirs of La Force.
sentences.chinese: 普吕戎这个名字，在拉弗尔斯监狱里是大伙儿记得的。

sentences.english: Look, they are all calling us.
sentences.chinese: 你看，大伙儿都在喊我们了。

sentences.english: A :"We always try to pretend that folks like him come by every day.
sentences.chinese: 大伙儿总是试图作出乐意他每天都来的样子。

sentences.english: I was shocked by the reactions to my need for cyber privacy.
sentences.chinese: 大伙儿对我渴望网络隐私一事的反应让我吃惊不已。

definition: I or me/we (including both the speaker and the person spoken to)
we or us (including both the speaker and the person(s) spoken to)/(dialect) I or me/(dialect) (in a coaxing or familiar way) you/also pr. [za2 men5]
(final particle equivalent to 了[le5])/(particle calling attention to, or mildly warning of, a situation)
old man/I (an old man referring to himself)
I/me/my/(often used in early vernacular literature)
plural marker for pronouns, and nouns referring to individuals
